title: Test-based versus parent ratings of executive function in pediatric Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

sections.title: 1.. Introduction
sections.text:
Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is a prevalent illness that often begins in childhood and causes significant distress and/or impairment in daily functioning  (American Psychiatric Association, 2013) . It has been hypothesized that differences in brain functioning in OCD-affected individuals  (Dougherty et al., 2018; Zohar, 2012)  may contribute to the observed functional impairment across diverse settings, including home, school, and community  (Negreiros, Belschner, Selles, Lin, & Stewart, 2018; Piacentini, Bergman, Keller, & McCracken, 2003; Sukhodolsky et al., 2005) . Neurocognitive assessment focusing on executive function (EF)  (Geller, 2006)  has been recognized as a valuable approach to understanding the role of implicated neuroanatomical structures of the brain of OCD-affected individuals  (Kuelz, Hohagen, & Voderholzer, 2004) . Evidence of neurocognitive functioning in OCD could lead to enhanced interventions to improve functioning across environments  (Freeman et al., 2014) .

EF has been broadly defined and is considered an "umbrella term," describing a number of inter-related complex cognitive processes associated with purposeful, goal-directed behaviors  (Anderson, 2002) . The risk of task impurity  (Miyake, Emerson, & Friedman, 2000)  has been a major concern in EF assessment, as each specific domain is embedded within a particular task context that is influenced by non-EF processes. To address these challenges, Miyake and colleagues  (Miyake & Friedman, 2012)  used confirmatory factor analysis and structural equation modelling techniques to capture purer EF domains. Three main EF processes were identified, including updating (related to working memory), shifting, and inhibition. These partially correlated processes were reported to both tap into a common underlying ability ("unity") and partially differ from one another, with unique relationships to other neurocognitive measures ("diversity")  (Miyake & Friedman, 2012) .

Operationalization of the term "executive function" has been an ongoing challenge as has the development of EF assessment tools with appropriate psychometric characteristics  (Chan, Shum, Toulopoulou, & Chen, 2008; Wong, 2004) . EF has historically been evaluated via either performance, test-based tasks or parent/self-ratings of daily behavior. However, these two types of measures have been poorly correlated across several childhood psychiatric and neurologic conditions  (Barkley & Fischer, 2011; Davidson, Cherry, & Corkum, 2016; Hybel, Lykke Mortensen, Højgaard, Lambek, & Hove Thomsen, 2017; MCaukey, Chen, Goss, Schachar, & Crosbie, 2010; Toplak, West, & Stanovich, 2013) , suggesting that they may assess differing underlying EF constructs that are relevant in structured versus unstructured conditions  (Hybel, Lykke Mortensen, Højgaard, Lambek, & Hove Thomsen, 2017; Toplak et al., 2013) .

On test-based EF tasks, goals are explicitly described with an aim to measure "processing efficiency of cognitive abilities" under ideal and very structured environmental conditions (e.g., quiet setting, free from distractions)  (Toplak et al., 2013) . In contrast, behavioral rating scales based on parent report assess the child's ability to function with or without distraction or support in one's regular environment. In other words, they reflect success in pursuing and/or accomplishing goals without explicit guidance in unstructured situations  (Toplak et al., 2013) . Despite critiques regarding the potential bias of using EF rating scales due to parents' subjective perceptions of their child's daily behavior, rating scales are perceived to be more ecologically valid measures than test-based tools  (Flanagan & Harrison, 2012) .

Illustrating differences with respect to assessment of inhibition, test performance captures the child's ability to quickly and accurately respond while suppressing the programmed response to a target shape, whereas parent reports capture their child's difficulty in resisting impulses and considering potential consequences of their actions before acting. Moreover, assessment of shifting based on test performance captures the child's ability to develop and maintain a problem-solving strategy across changing stimulus conditions, whereas parent reports captures the child's difficulty in making transitions or tolerating change  (Gioia, Isquith, Guy, & Kenworthy, 2001) .

While several OCD studies have examined executive dysfunction via standardized performance testing, very few have investigated reportbased daily behavior associated with EF deficits  (Hybel , Lykke  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jocrd.2019.100495 Received 19 September 2019; Received in revised form 8 November 2019; Accepted 10 November 2019  Mortensen et al., 2017; Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Højgaard, & Thomsen, 2017) . This is in contrast to research on ADHD  (Mcauley, Chen, Goos, Schachar, & Crosbie, 2010) , psychosis spectrum  (Gur et al., 2014) , epilepsy  (Hessen, Alfstad, Torgersen, & Lossius, 2018)  and traumatic brain injury  (Vriezen & Pigott, 2002)  populations. Adding more ecologically valid measures to EF assessment  (Isquith, Roth, & Gioia, 2013)  is central to providing critical information about OCDaffected youth's daily behavior in real-life contexts and across environments and conditions. This is important given the potential influences of OCD-related distress on cognitive function.

sections.title: 1.1.. Test-based measures of EF in OCD
sections.text:
Most test-based OCD neurocognitive studies have examined adult populations. All three meta-analyses of adult OCD neurocognition studies  (Abramovitch, Abramowitz, & Mittelman, 2013; Shin, Lee, Kim, & Kwon, 2014; Snyder et al., 2016)  identified weaknesses in EF, attention, processing speed, nonverbal memory, and visuospatial tasks. Few related studies have been conducted in pediatric OCD, with the only meta-analysis  (Abramovitch, Abramowitz, et al., 2015)  reporting no more than small effect sizes across varied neurocognitive domains. As such, discrepancies appear to exist between neurocognitive weaknesses in adult versus pediatric OCD, based upon performance testing  (Abramovitch, Abramowitz, et al., 2015; Abramovitch, Mittelman, Tankersley, Abramowitz, & Schweiger, 2015; Geller et al., 2018) .

Pediatric studies of test-based neurocognition in OCD have yielded variable results. While some identified no differences  (Beers et al., 1999) , others found poorer performance in planning, set shifting, response inhibition, and spatial working memory  (Andrés et al., 2007; Ornstein, Arnold, Manassis, Mendlowitz, & Schachar, 2010; Purcell, Maruff, Kyrios, & Pantelis, 1998) , in addition to short-term memory and visual-constructional skills  (Garcia-Delgar et al., 2018; Olley, Malhi, & Sachdev, 2007) . McGuire and colleagues (McGuire et al., 2014)  reported that OCD-affected youth with symmetry/ordering but not hoarding demonstrated worse response inhibition and set shifting than healthy controls (HC). In addition to those domains, OCD-affected youth with symmetry/ordering and hoarding symptoms demonstrated poorer memory, verbal learning, fluency, and processing speed.

The question of whether putative neurocognition differences represent precursors, sequelae or a combination of both within pediatric OCD remains unconfirmed. In the only pediatric endophenotype OCD neurocognition study to date, poorer planning was found in both OCDaffected and in unaffected, genetically at-risk siblings compared to controls, identifying it as a putative susceptibility marker preceding illness  (Negreiros et al., 2019) . Studies have reported improvement of neurocognitive deficits in OCD-affected youth following treatment, suggesting that performance may change over time  (Andrés et al., 2008; Huyser, Veltman, Wolters, De Haan, & Boer, 2010; Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Højgaard, et al., 2017; van der Straten, Huyser, Wolters, Denys, & van Wingen, 2018) . As such, planning may be a marker preceding illness that also shifts with disease course.

sections.title: 1.2.. Parent ratings of EF in pediatric OCD
sections.text:
The few studies assessing parent ratings of EF in OCD-affected youth  (Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Højgaard, et al., 2017; Hybel, Mortensen, et al., 2017; McNamara et al., 2014; Zandt, Prior, & Kyrios, 2009)  found significantly worse EF in comparison to HCs. Hybel and colleagues  (Hybel, Lykke Mortensen et al., 2017)  found that all three subgroups of OCD-affected youth (characterized by the symmetry/hoarding, harm/ sexual, and contamination/cleaning symptom dimensions) had greater parent-reported daily behavior problems associated with inhibition and shifting compared to controls. The only EF subdomain that differentiated between the OCD groups was working memory (for which the contamination/cleaning subgroup had more reported problem behaviors). Of note, the authors found no associations among OCD participants between EF scores (ratings or test-based performance) and any symptom dimensions.

Another pediatric OCD study investigating ratings of EF divided youth into those with and without hoarding symptoms and identified greater discrepancies in the latter group  (Park et al., 2016) . In yet another study, OCD severity was associated with report-based EF domains, and emotional control deficits were predictive of multimodal treatment outcome  (McNamara et al., 2014) . Finally, EF daily behavior has been shown to improve after CBT, suggesting that it may be significantly influenced by OCD symptomatology  (Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Højgaard, et al., 2017) .

sections.title: 1.3.. Multimodal test-based measures and parent ratings of EF in pediatric OCD
sections.text: When examining both test-based and report-based EF, Zandt and colleagues' findings  (Zandt et al., 2009)  highlighted the dissociation between measure findings. In their study, poorer parent ratings of EF in OCD (n = 17) and Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) (n = 19) groups was found relative to controls (n = 18) across all composites. In contrast, on test-based assessment, the OCD group demonstrated poorer inhibition but not poorer planning, verbal fluency, or cognitive flexibility in comparison to HCs. Given its small sample size, this study did not enable more detailed comparison of these measure outcomes in pediatric OCD.

sections.title: 2.. Objective
sections.text: In an attempt to better understand how OCD-affected youth perform under an ideal versus real-life contexts, this study examined test-based and parent ratings of EF (i.e., shifting, inhibition, planning, and working memory) in OCD-affected youth and HCs. Secondly, this study investigated potential relationships between test -and report-based measures of EF. It was hypothesized that OCD-affected youth would demonstrate more widespread EF deficits when captured by reports of daily behavior versus test performance in controlled settings. It was further hypothesized that significant relationships would not be identified between corresponding measures intending to capture EF domains. Additional associations between the outcome measures and OCD severity and OCD symptom dimensions were further examined. It was hypothesized that both OCD severity and OCD symptom dimensions would not be correlated with the any of the outcome measures. This study was part of a larger project investigating endophenotypes in pediatric OCD.

sections.title: 3.1.. Participants
sections.text: A total of 118 study participants, ranging between 6 and 18 years of age (M = 12.69, SD = 2.74), were recruited as part of a larger study. The majority of the sample was female (n = 78; 66%), Caucasian (n = 91; 81%), and had parents who completed at least some postsecondary education (mother n = 109; 96%; father n = 96; 85%). OCDaffected participants were recruited from a population of youth referred to an OCD program at a public tertiary care children's hospital between January 2013 and June 2019. Youth and their parents provided assent/ consent at their initial clinic assessment or during participation in the program's group family-based CBT program (GF-CBT). HCs were recruited through community advertisements and word of mouth. Demographic and clinical characteristics of the sample are provided in Table  1 .

sections.title: 3.2.. Procedures
sections.text:
The study was approved by the institutional research ethics board.

Written consent and assent were provided by a parent/legal guardian and the youth, respectively. For the OCD group, PhD-level clinic psychologists administered semi-structured interviews to confirm OCD diagnosis and to assess comorbidities, and their diagnoses were confirmed by the clinic's psychiatrists. For the HC group, following screening procedures, trained Masters-level psychology research assistants, who were supervised by PhD-level psychologists, administered the same semi-structured clinical interview to parents.

The general inclusion criteria to participate in the study were: youth between ages 6 and 18 years, able to communicate effectively in English, and with an IQ standard score of at least 80. For the OCD group, participants had a current DSM-IV-TR Axis I diagnosis of childhood-onset OCD but none of the following comorbidities: (a) current major depressive disorder (MDD), bipolar disorder, psychosis, intellectual disability or ASD, and (b) lifetime substance dependence/ abuse disorder. The exclusion criteria for the HC group were lifetime DSM-IV-TR Axis I psychiatric disorder and having OCD or Tourette syndrome in a first-degree relative. MDD was listed as an exclusion factor given evidence that MDD-affected children  (Wagner, Müller, Helmreich, Huss, & Tadić, 2015)  and adults  (Rock, Roiser, Riedel, & Blackwell, 2014)  demonstrate a wide range of neurocognitive deficits, which could confound study results.

Among individuals consenting to participate, one OCD-affected youth was excluded following diagnosis of psychosis on the semistructured diagnostic interview, and six OCD-affected participants were excluded based on their low IQ score (standard score < 80).

Following study entry, parents completed demographic and medical background questionnaires and their youth participated in a 2-3-hour neurocognitive assessment session conducted by Masters-or PhD-level psychology researchers trained and supervised by the first author. To maximize recruitment rates, participants were offered the option of participating in the assessment session either at the British Columbia Children's Hospital or at their house. Data quality checks were completed twice to ensure accuracy.

sections.title: 3.3.1.. Anxiety disorders interview schedule for parent IV (ADIS-P)
sections.text: The ADIS-P  (Silverman & Albano, 1996)  is a semi-structured interview widely used in clinical trials to assess psychiatric disorders in youth. The reliability of the ADIS-P has been thoroughly tested and found to range from good to excellent (internal consistency of 0.73-0.92 for youth;  Silverman, Saavedra, & Pina, 2001) . To determine eligibility for study participation, a parent of all participants was administered the ADIS-P to confirm or disconfirm an OCD diagnosis and to assess for comorbidities.

sections.title: 3.3.2.. Children's Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (CY-BOCS) and Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (YBOCS)
sections.text: The CY-BOCS  (Scahill et al., 1997)  and the Y-BOCS  (Goodman et al., 1989)  are clinician-administered, semi-structured questionnaires of symptoms and severity of OCD. These are considered as gold-standard tools for use in clinical and research settings. Regarding total severity score, inter-rater reliability (Y-BOCS r = 0.80-0.99; CY-BOCS r = 0.87-   (Gallant et al., 2008; Rapp, Bergman, Piacentini, & McGuire, 2016; Scahill et al., 1997; Storch et al., 2004) . The CY-BOCS and the Y-BOCS are divided into two components. The first comprises the obsessive-compulsive checklist of current and life-long OCD symptoms. The second assesses severity of obsessions and compulsions as identified by their frequency, distress, interference, ability to resist, and perceived control over symptoms. OCD-affected youth's symptom dimensions were determined based on Bloch et al.'s meta-analytic results  (Bloch, Landeros-Weisenberger, Leckman, Rosario, & Pittenger, 2008)  describing a four-factor symptom structure, comprising hoarding (hoarding obsessions and compulsions), symmetry (symmetry obsessions and ordering, repeating, and counting compulsions), forbidden thoughts (aggression, sexual, and religious obsessions), and cleaning (contamination obsessions and cleaning compulsions). Both components were administered by PhD-level clinic psychologists at the OCDaffected youth's initial clinic assessment, and the second component was repeated on the day of the neurocognitive assessment.

sections.title: 3.3.3.. Wechsler abbreviated scale of intelligence -second edition (WASI-II)
sections.text: The WASI-II  (Wechsler, 2011 ) is a revised brief cognitive measure of intelligence for individuals between ages 6 and 90 years, 11 months. The WASI-II has updated norms and reportedly high reliability coefficients (greater than 0.80;  McCrimmon & Smith, 2013) . To estimate general cognitive ability (IQ), the full-scale score (FSIQ-2) derived from the Vocabulary and the Matrix Reasoning subtests was used.

sections.title: 3.3.4.. Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery (CANTAB)
sections.text: The CANTAB is a computerized set of cognitive tests presented on a high-resolution color monitor with a touch-sensitive screen widely used in research  (CANTAB, 2018)  to assess cognitive abilities associated with the frontal and medial temporal areas of the brain  (Robbins et al., 1994; Strauss, Sherman, & Spreen, 2006) . In the current study, four performance-based EF tests were administered to participants, including the Intra-Extra Dimensional Set Shift task (IED total error correct score) to assess shifting ability, the Stop Signal Task (SST ssrt score) to assess inhibition, the Stockings of Cambridge task (SOC mean 5 moves) to measure planning, and the Spatial Working Memory task (SWM between error score) to assess spatial working memory. Given the large number of provided scores for each of the CANTAB tests, the current specific score selection was conducted a priori based on those scores mostly used in peer-reviewed articles examining neurocognitive functioning using the CANTAB across child psychiatric populations.

sections.title: 3.3.5.. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
sections.text: The BRIEF  (Gioia et al., 2001 ) is an 86-item questionnaire that assesses parents' or teacher's perspectives of youth's daily behavior associated with domains of EF, including shift, inhibition, emotional control, initiate, working memory, plan/organize, monitor, and organization of materials. The frequency of specific problem behaviors is rated on a 3-point Likert scale. T-scores of ≥ 65 indicate clinically significant behavior problems in a given domain. There are over 400 peer-reviewed publications supporting the reliability, validity, and clinical utility of the BRIEF  (Roth, Erdodi, McCulloch, & Isquith, 2015) . In the current study, participants' parents rated their child's daily behavior associated with the domains of shift, inhibition, plan/organize, and working memory.

sections.title: 3.3.6.. State anxiety
sections.text: The "state" section of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory for Children (STAIC; ages 6-13) or the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI; ages 14-18)  (Spielberger, 1973) , as appropriate, was used to assess participants' anxiety state before the assessment started. Psychometric data for the STAI-C/STAI is generally adequate, including internal consistency (α = 0.80-0.91), test-retest coefficients (r = 0.31-0.70), and convergent and divergent validity  (Barnes, Harp, & Jung, 2002) .

sections.title: 3.4.1.. Matching of OCD and HC participants
sections.text: OCD-affected participants were matched to HCs via propensity score matching using the 'MatchIt' library  (Ho, King, Stuart, & Imai, 2011 ) (version 3.0.2) in R version 3.6.0 (r-project.org). This was done in an effort to optimize comparability of the groups across all aspects that may influence outcome measures, other than a diagnosis of OCD. First, a logistic regression model was fitted to group membership (OCD versus HC) using age, gender, ethnicity (Caucasian versus other), state anxiety, and FSIQ-2. These variables were selected due to their theoretical associations with neurocognitive performance and/or to adjust for imbalance between the non-randomly assigned groups. The quality of matching was evaluated across minor adjustments of the matching algorithm, and the set of specifications that produced the highest quality matching was defined as that which: 1) allow for a single HC participant to match to more than one OCD-affected participant, 2) discard OCD and HC participants who did not match, and 3) re-evaluate the degree of matching after discarding participants. Importantly, the determination of the best matched sample was conducted without knowledge of each participant's BRIEF and CANTAB scores and, therefore, decisions regarding these specifications were not influenced by the primary study goal of examining group differences in the BRIEF and CANTAB scores.

sections.title: 3.4.2.. Group differences analyses
sections.text:
Following matching, group differences in the BRIEF and the CANTAB domains were evaluated using weighted linear regression, with the weights being derived from the previous matching algorithm. All OCD-affected participants had a weight of 1, whereas HCs received a weight proportional to the number of participants with OCD with whom they matched. Following the recommendations of Wan  (Wan, 2019) , the regression model included the covariates used in the initial matching procedure (i.e., age, gender, ethnicity, state anxiety, and IQ). Table  2  shows the adjusted means and standard errors (SE) for each group, along with the between-group effect size (expressed as Cohen's d) and p-value. Examination of residual plots suggested heteroskedasticity in the residuals across outcomes; thus, heteroskedasticity consistent standard errors  (Long & Ervin, 2000)  were computed using the 'sandwich' library in R.

Additional independent t-test comparisons were performed to rule out the potential influence of: (a) assessment location (clinic versus home), (b) current participation in CBT, and (c) current use of psychotropic medication on neurocognitive performance.

sections.title: 3.4.3.. Associations between test-based and parent ratings of EF
sections.text: A final set of models examined the association between a given CANTAB test score (e.g., IED) and its corresponding BRIEF domain score (e.g., shift). Weighted linear regression was used with the BRIEF score as the dependent variable, the corresponding CANTAB score as the predictor of interest, and the covariates included previously. We included the group by CANTAB score interaction to determine whether the association between CANTAB and BRIEF score differed for OCD and HC participants. When non-significant (p > .05), this interaction was dropped to allow for the estimation of the association between CANTAB and BRIEF scores across OCD and HC participants. As previously, heteroskedasticity consistent standard errors were computed.

sections.title: 3.4.4.. Associations between outcome measures and OCD severity and OCD symptom dimensions
sections.text: In addition, associations between each CANTAB and BRIEF measure and OCD severity (CY-BOCS score) and symptom dimensions (fourfactor model) was computed within the OCD group. To improve statistical power and precision, data from the larger OCD cohort (n = 103) was used rather than the smaller matched sample (n = 75).

sections.title: 3.4.5.. Correction for multiple testing
sections.text: To correct for multiple testing, first, an alpha = .025 was allocated to the family of BRIEF outcomes and .025 to the family of CANTAB outcomes. Second, because the outcomes were correlated, the approach outlined by Nyholt  (Nyholt, 2004)  to calculate the effective number of tests and divide alpha = .025 by this number was used. This approach resulted in a final alpha threshold of .007 for CANTAB outcomes and an alpha threshold of .01 for BRIEF outcomes.

sections.title: 4.1.. Matched sample
sections.text: The matched sample used for the current analysis was drawn from a larger sample of 103 OCD-affected participants and 84 HCs (see Table  S1  for descriptive characteristics of the initial sample). The highest quality matched sample included 75 OCD-affected participants and 43 HCs. Fig.  S1  shows the distribution of propensity scores for matched and unmatched participants. Tables  S1  and  S2  provide a summary of the characteristics of the total and the matched samples, respectively, based on the covariates (i.e., age, gender, ethnicity, state anxiety, and IQ).

sections.title: 4.2.. Group differences on EF measures
sections.text:
Table  2  summarizes the group differences estimated from the weighted least squares regression models, and Fig.  1  provides a visual representation of group differences on the outcome measures and a comparison between parent rating-and test-based scores. For clearer comparisons and readability, values have been standardized (M = 0, SD = 1).

Group differences in test performance across CANTAB domains were small. Spatial working memory (Cohen's d = .62; p = .003) was the only EF domain in which the OCD group demonstrated significantly poorer performance compared to HCs following correction for multiple comparisons at an alpha threshold of .007. While not reaching statistical significance, OCD-affected participants demonstrated poorer planning performance with small to medium effect size (Cohen's d = 0.42; p = .03). Between group differences in shifting and inhibition were much smaller (Cohen's d = .04; p = .88 and Cohen's d = 0.21; p = .20, respectively) and found to be non-significant.

In contrast, across all parent-reported BRIEF domains, OCD-affected participants had significantly higher mean scores than their matched HC peers, with large effect sizes in shift (Cohen's d = 1.36; p < .001), working memory (Cohen's d = 0.92; p < .001), planning (Cohen's d = 0.89; p < .001), and inhibition (Cohen's d = 0.78; p < .001). Table  S4  provides mean T-scores for each group and the percentage of participants who scored within the clinically significant range (Tscore ≥ 65). Despite the fact that the mean T-score of the OCD-affected group did not reach clinically significant levels across domains, 37% of OCD-affected youth (n = 27) fell within the clinically significant range in the shift domain, followed by 34% in working memory (n = 25), 25% in planning (n = 15), and 14% in inhibition (n = 10). In comparison, almost no HCs fell within the clinically significant range in any domain (n = 0-1).

Group differences in neurocognitive performance (i.e., CANTAB and BRIEF) were not significantly impacted by assessment location, current participation in CBT, or current use of psychotropic medication (Tables  S6-S8 ).

sections.title: 4.3.. Associations between test-based and parent ratings of EF measures
sections.text: The associations between CANTAB-task performance and BRIEF ratings are presented in Table  3 . No significant associations between CANTAB and corresponding BRIEF domains were found for either group or the combined sample (i.e., shifting: standardized beta = .05; inhibition: standardized beta = 0.20; planning: standardized beta = -0.03; and working memory: standardized beta = 0.13). Furthermore, in examining the overall associations across the two groups, associations were estimated to be small and indistinguishable from zero, after accounting for the covariates (i.e., shifting: standardized beta = 0.03; inhibition: standardized beta = 0.16; planning: standardized beta = -0.08; and working memory: standardized beta = 0.12).

sections.title: 4.4.. Associations between outcome measures and OCD severity and OCD symptom dimensions
sections.text: No significant associations were identified between the CANTAB and BRIEF scores and symptom severity (CY-BOCS) within the OCD group as presented in Table  S5 . Furthermore, Table  4  displays test-and rating-based EF scores for OCD-affected youth presenting with and without each of the four OCD symptom dimensions (i.e., hoarding, symmetry, forbidden thoughts, and cleaning). These findings provide limited evidence that EF performance was influenced by the presence of cleaning, forbidden thoughts, or hoarding dimensions. However, the symmetry symptom dimension was moderately associated with testbased planning (Cohen's d = -0.64) and spatial working memory (Cohen's d = -0.62) scores without adjustment for multiple testing.

sections.title: 5.. Discussion
sections.text:
To the authors' knowledge, this is the largest study in the pediatric OCD literature to assess and compare both test-and parent report-based measures of EF in OCD-affected youth versus HCs. Significant discrepancy between test-based and parent ratings of EF in pediatric OCD suggests that assessing daily EF behaviors can be a valuable way to capture previously underrecognized difficulties in functioning. In line with the few pediatric OCD studies to date that assessed daily EF behaviors  (Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Thastum, et al., 2017; McNamara et al., 2014; Zandt et al., 2009) , EF-related behavior problems in "less controlled," everyday real-world contexts appear to occur more commonly in OCD-affected youth than in HCs, with comparably large effect sizes. A notable segment of the OCD group scored within the clinically  significant range across shift (37%), working memory (34%), planning (25%) and inhibition (14%) domains. However, when conducted in a highly controlled setting, weaknesses in test-based EF tasks were less dramatic (i.e., poorer spatial working memory and planning). Consistent with two previous pediatric OCD studies  (Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Højgaard, et al., 2017; Zandt et al., 2009) , ADHD studies  (Barkley & Fischer, 2011; Davidson et al., 2016; Toplak et al., 2013) , and other literature  (Dawson & Guare, 2004; Toplak et al., 2013) , no significant associations were found between CANTAB and corresponding BRIEF domains for either group or the combined sample.

When working with OCD-affected youth, clinicians may greatly benefit from assessing their patient's daily EF via ratings, as such information could help with case conceptualization, intervention development, and evaluation of changes in pre-and post-treatment outcomes  (Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Højgaard, et al., 2017) . For example, items on the BRIEF shift domain can inform whether one is able to problem solve with flexibility, to tolerate frustration when unexpected changes occur, or to switch from one activity or task to another without any major difficulty. Similarly, ratings on the BRIEF plan/organize domain can inform whether one's ability to manage current and future-oriented task demands (e.g., homework/chore completion) is age appropriate. Having knowledge about youth's weaknesses in these areas could assist in the development of interventions aiming to improve treatment outcomes and school and family functioning.

Interestingly, BRIEF scores were not associated with OCD severity, suggesting that parent ratings of their child's daily behavior were not merely a result of OCD severity. Such lack of association could be due to the different constructs that these measures assessed such as the severity and intensity of obsession and compulsions over the previous week (CY-BOCS) versus daily behaviors related to self-control and problem-solving skills (BRIEF). In addition, the informants of these measures were not the same (parents versus youth). Based on documented improvements on ratings of daily behavior following treatment  (Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Højgaard, et al., 2017) , it appears that results on the BRIEF were influenced by the overall impact of OCD symptoms on daily routines and/or life situations rather than by the severity of symptoms reported on a specific week. To better understand how EF behavior problems are related to general life conditions across environments, future studies may consider examining associations between daily EF behavior and overall life and school functioning in pediatric OCD populations. Furthermore, potential influences of parent gender and other family factors on BRIEF ratings are also worth exploring.

With respect to test-based results, spatial working memory and planning were found to be areas of weaknesses in pediatric OCD. Evidence regarding OCD-affected individual's weaknesses in spatial working memory has been documented in two OCD adult meta-analytic studies  (Abramovitch et al., 2013; Snyder et al., 2016)  with small and medium to large effect sizes, respectively, and in one OCD endophenotype adult study  (De Vries et al., 2014) . However, evidence of spatial working memory weakness in pediatric OCD populations is scarce  (Abramovitch, Abramowitz, et al., 2015; Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Thastum, et al., 2017; Negreiros et al., 2019) , and larger pediatric OCD studies that assess spatial working memory are needed to support our findings. In terms of planning, there was some evidence for a moderate difference in the CANTAB planning score, though the difference was not deemed statistically significant after accounting for multiple tests. Significant planning weakness in pediatric OCD has been found in the only child OCD endophenotype study  (Negreiros et al., 2019)  and in four smaller adult OCD endophenotype studies  (Cavedini, Zorzi, Piccinni, Cavallini, & Bellodi, 2010; Delorme et al., 2007; Li, Sun, Li, & Yang, 2012; Segalas et al., 2010)  conducted with unaffected relatives, as well as with other OCD case-control neurocognition adult and child studies  (Andrés et al., 2007; Ornstein et al., 2010) . No meaningful differences on inhibition and shifting tasks were found, which is consistent with other pediatric OCD studies  (Abramovitch, Abramowitz, et al., 2015; Hybel, Mortensen, Lambek, Thastum, et al., 2017; Negreiros et al., 2019) . Null findings could also be related to the fact that test-based EF tasks are not designed to capture more subtle brain activation deficits in youth but rather to assess "gross" deficits  (Gruner & Pittenger, 2017) . Thus, future studies that examine neural and clinical neurocognitive correlates of pediatric OCD are needed.

Another strong finding was the lack of significant associations between test-based and parent ratings of EF in each assessed domain, suggesting that these measures assess different underlying constructs. Such discrepancy could be explained by a range of factors including (a) inconsistency with the operationalization of the term EF and its domains, (b) concerns with task specificity and impurity, (c) limited numbers of developmentally appropriate standardized EF measures for children, (d) low test-retest reliability of test-based EF tools, (e) limited process-behavior correspondence  (Anderson, 2002; Baron, 2003; Miyake et al., 2000; Strauss et al., 2006) , (f) lack of ecological validity of test-based measures  (Dawson & Guare, 2004; Isquith et al., 2013; Kapur, 2005 Kapur, 2004)) , and (f) different methods of measurement (test performance versus parent ratings  (Flanagan & Harrison, 2012) . While behavioral rating scales may identify the individual's ability to function with or without distraction or support in his/her regular environment, performance-based testing provides information about one's executive functioning under ideal environmental conditions. Thus, these two classes of measures should not be interpreted as equivalent, interchangeable, or as types or subcategories of one another, especially because these measures appear to assess different underlying constructs  (Barkley & Fischer, 2011; Davidson et al., 2016; Hybel, Lykke; Mortensen et al., 2017; MCaukey et al., 2010; Toplak et al., 2013)  Based on the aforementioned factors, we believe that the BRIEF provides more meaningful information about OCD-affected youth's ability to perform tasks reliant on EF in their real environment in comparison to results derived from test-based assessment. Such observable executive deficits of daily functioning could be potentially influenced by the manifestation of youth's OCD symptoms caused by environmental triggers. Therefore, future studies that examine interactions between OCD symptom provocation and test-based EF deserve exploration. Interestingly, executive dysfunction using the BRIEF has also been identified in other clinical populations such as of youth with ADHD  (Davidson et al., 2016)  or ASD  (Gilotty, Kenworthy, Sirian, Black, & Wagner, 2002) . Despite the current study not identifying significant associations between symptom dimensions and BRIEF ratings, it is possible that BRIEF results are conflated by OCD symptom presentation. As opposed to other disorders, where this has been directly examined (e.g., ADHD, ASD), the potential overlap between OCD phenotype and BRIEF domains requires further study. It is suggested that the BRIEF may be a useful tool to discriminate between individuals with and without a mental health diagnosis, but not to specify the type of diagnosis. More research that investigates whether different clinical populations have unique EF behavior profiles on the BRIEF is warranted. Finally, a few, but not meaningful, associations between test-and rating-based outcome measures and the four OCD symptom dimensions were found. More specifically, there were moderate relationships between symmetry and test-based planning and spatial working memory scores. However, as we did not adjust for multiple testing, this finding is perceived as an interesting possibility but not necessarily as a confirmation that youth with symmetry symptoms have worse test performance on planning and working memory tasks. Symmetry/ordering symptoms are often associated with "Tourettic OCD" with reported limited improvement following CBT  (McGuire, Tan, & Piacentini, 2019) . In light of our findings, OCD-affected youth with symmetry/ ordering symptoms may struggle with planning and working memory in the context of CBT, contributing to poorer treatment response. As such, clinicians may want to be mindful of these potential weaknesses when providing CBT for this population. While our results were mostly similar to Hybel et al.'s null findings  (Hybel, Lykke Mortensen et al., 2017) , our findings also diverged from two other pediatric studies that investigated such associations. In terms of test-based measures,  McGuire et al. (McGuire et al., 2014)  reported that youth with symmetry/ordering symptoms (not including hoarding) had worse shifting task performance (among other tasks not assessed in the current study) in comparison to youth without those symptoms. Regarding ratings of EF, Park and colleagues  (Park et al., 2016)  found significant correlations between hoarding symptoms and problem behavior associated with inhibition and working memory. It is possible that discrepancies between study findings occurred due to different symptom dimension clustering procedures. While a 4-factor symptom dimension model was used in our study, which derived from Bloch et al.'s meta-analytic results  (Bloch et al., 2008)    (Hybel, Lykke Mortensen et al., 2017), and Park et al. applied a dichotomous model (hoarders versus non-hoarders; Park et al., 2016) . Different findings could also be attributed to small sample sizes (e.g., in Hybel et al.'s study, group sizes ranged between 8 and 30 participants per symptom dimension) or to the administration of different test-based measures.

sections.title: 6.. Limitations
sections.text: While the BRIEF provided information about parents' perceptions of their child's daily behavior associated with EF, results may represent their unique perspective of their child's behavior. To identify the best informant regarding a child's psychopathology and behavior, it is suggested that the child's age (i.e., younger versus older), the problem type (i.e., internalizing versus externalizing), and the setting (i.e., inpatient versus outpatient) be considered  (Smith, 2007) . Thus, including multiple observers' perspectives on individuals' everyday behavior could also provide a more comprehensive view than a single observer. Using both test-and rating-based measures of EF may be relevant, as these tools seem to identify different manifestations of EF impairment in an "ideal" versus "real-world" settings  (Isquith et al., 2013; Strauss et al., 2006) . Future studies of this type should capture measures of quality of life, family environment (e.g., accommodation and functioning), and school functioning to help disentangle environmental influences on EF. Finally, applications to clinical practice should be further investigated.

sections.title: 7.. Conclusions
sections.text: This is the largest study examining EF in OCD-affected youth in comparison to the matched peers using both test-based measures and parent ratings of EF. Findings suggest that OCD-affected youth demonstrate greater executive dysfunction in real-life contexts (BRIEF) in which OCD symptoms may interfere more than in controlled settings (CANTAB). Discrepancies between test-and rating-based measures of EF suggest that these tools assess different underlying constructs and should not be used interchangeably. Information about OCD-affected youth's daily EF behavior can be valuable to assist clinicians with case conceptualization, intervention development, and evaluation of changes in pre-and post-OCD treatment outcomes.
